intro: Camelina pinnatifida, commonly known as the narrow-leaved camelina, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia and North America. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important crops such as mustard and broccoli. The plant is characterized by its pinnately divided leaves and small, yellowish flowers that bloom in clusters. It typically grows in dry, open habitats and is often found in disturbed soils. Camelina pinnatifida is also noted for its potential as a source of oilseed and its adaptability to various environmental conditions.
